As the number of cases continues to rise in the US, it is important that the government takes a more measured and effective approach to tackling the pandemic. Travel restrictions and quarantines may seem like a quick fix, but in reality, they are proving to be counterproductive and harmful to the economy.

Despite several warnings, workers are forced to work in close proximity to each other and customers, increasing the risk of infection. To address this, a committee of workers and management has been formed to identify these scenarios and recommend suitable interventions. The committee has recommended the use of appropriate combinations of controls following the hierarchy of controls to limit the spread of COVID-19. The first control measure recommended is engineering controls such as the installation of physical barriers between workers and customers. Additionally, the use of contactless payment methods and curbside pickup can also be employed to reduce contact between workers and customers. Administrative controls such as staggering work schedules and implementing shift rotations have also been suggested. This would reduce the number of workers present in the workplace at any given time, reducing the risk of transmission. Lastly, personal protective equipment (PPE) such as masks and gloves have been recommended for workers who are unable to maintain social distancing. Employers have a responsibility to provide adequate PPE to their workers and ensure that they are using them correctly. While protecting workers is of utmost importance, it is equally essential to note that control recommendations or interventions to reduce the risk of COVID-19 are necessary to protect customers as well. It is high time that employers take the necessary measures to protect their workers and customers during these unprecedented times. Failure to do so could result in an outbreak in the workplace, putting the lives of countless individuals at risk.

The US Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use (US MEC) and the Selected Practice Recommendations for Contraceptive Use (US SPR) have recommended that healthcare providers should limit the use of contraceptives during this time. However, this has raised concerns among many women's rights groups who argue that access to family planning services is essential, especially during a pandemic. The Quality Family Planning Services (QFP) has come out in support of these groups and has recommended that healthcare providers continue to offer these services while taking necessary precautions. Additionally, they have recommended that healthcare providers should use personal protective equipment (PPE) and take necessary precautions when providing in-person services. The QFP has also urged healthcare providers to educate their patients about the risks and benefits of using contraceptives during the pandemic. While the pandemic has created unprecedented challenges for healthcare providers, the QFP believes that access to family planning services should not be compromised. They have called on healthcare providers to remain vigilant in providing these services while taking necessary precautions to keep themselves and their patients safe.

ai_content: Numerous manufacturers offer NIOSH-approved respirators that come in various sizes and models for a wide range of uses in occupational settings.
